description: From Ancient Greek δίσκος (dískos, “a circular plate suited for hurling”), from δικέω (dikéō, “to hurl, to launch”). Doublet of dais, desk, disc, discus, dish, and diskos.

entries.meaning: A thin, flat, circular plate or similar object.
examples: A coin is a disk of metal.
Venus' disk cut off light from the Sun.
Turn the disk over, after it has finished.

entries.meaning: (computer hardware) Ellipsis of floppy disk - removable magnetic medium or a hard disk - fixed, persistent digital storage.
examples: He still uses floppy disks from 1979.

entries.meaning: (computer hardware, nonstandard) A disc - either a CD-ROM, an audio CD, a DVD or similar removable storage medium.
examples: She burned some disks yesterday to back up her computer.

entries.meaning: (botany) A ring- or cup-shaped enlargement of the flower receptacle or ovary that bears nectar or, less commonly, the stamens.

verbs.description: disk (third-person singular simple present disks, present participle disking, simple past and past participle disked)

entries.meaning: (aviation, of an aircraft's propeller) To move towards, or operate at, zero blade pitch, orienting the propeller blades face-on to the oncoming airstream and maximizing the drag generated by the propeller.
